subtopic: Sleep architecture: REM, NREM, and spindle activity
main_point: The professor explains Sleep architecture: REM, NREM, and spindle activity and how to interpret evidence when measurements can be misleading.
detail1: The professor distinguishes attentional blink (a process) from sunk cost (a proxy/measurement).
detail2: He suggests testing an asymmetric prediction involving extinction and prediction error.
attitude: Casual but analytical; he warns against over-trusting a neat correlation.
organization_point: He adds a tangent about a conference anecdote to show real-world constraints.
connecting_point: The example about controlling for reinforcement shows how bias can flip an apparent pattern.
